questions.text: A 33-year-old man presents with high fever, headache, myalgia, vomiting, and diarrhea. Two weeks ago, he returned from Africa, where he was taking care of patients infected with filovirus.A serum RT-PCR reaction confirms infection with a filovirus. Which of the following is the most likely route of transmission of the causal pathogen?eeks ago, he returned from Africa, where he was taking care of patients infected with filovirus. His mucous membranes appear dry. Laboratory studies show leukopenia, thrombocytopenia, and elevated serum transaminases. A serum RT-PCR reaction confirms infection with a filovirus. Which of the following is the most likely route of transmission of the causal pathogen?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Filoviruses are transmitted through contact with body fluid.
  • Filoviruses are pleomorphic particles appearing as filamentous threads as shown below or irregular shapes and include Marburg and Ebola viruses
  • Marburg and Ebola viruses are antigenically distinct and belong to different genera. Ebola virus has four subtypes: Zaire, Sudan, Reston, and Ivory Coast.
  • Their genome is a single-stranded, negative-sense, nonsegmented RNA and are highly virulent, requiring Biosafety Level 4 containment.
  • African fruit bats are suspected natural hosts.

The lifecycle of Ebola virus is as shown below.

  • Marburg and Ebola viruses cause African hemorrhagic fevers in humans and nonhuman primates.
  • Symptoms appear after an incubation of 3 - 9 days for Marburg and 2-21 days for Ebola, beginning with fever, headache, sore throat, and muscle pain, followed by abdominal symptoms, rash, and internal and external bleeding, often progressing to shock and death.
  • Filovirus infections are often immunosuppressive, with fatal cases showing impaired humoral immunity.
  • Antibodies appear during recovery and can be detected by ELISA. Viral antigens and RNA can also be detected via ELISA and RT-PCR.
  • Reservoirs are likely fruit bats, with human transmission occurring occasionally. Human-to-human spread occurs through direct contact with blood, body fluids, or contaminated materials, often in healthcare settings. (Options A, B, and D ruled out)
  • Control relies on strict isolation, barrier nursing, and extreme caution when handling infected materials. There is no specific antiviral therapy, but experimental antibody treatments and vaccines are under development.
  • Management focuses on supportive care, maintaining renal and electrolyte balance, and controlling hemorrhage and shock. An experimental vaccine is being tested for outbreak control.

questions.text: A previously healthy 27-year-old man presents with fever, chills, headache, and severe muscle aches for the past 3 days. He returned from Korea 2 weeks ago, where he was involved in monitoring agricultural barns. His BP is 80/60 mm Hg and hematocrit is rising. He is also noted to have oliguria and his creatinine is 2.4mg/dl. Which of the following is the most likely infectious agent?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The given clinical features of fever, muscle aches, history of working in agricultural barn in Korea along with renal involvement and rising hematocrit is suggestive of hemorrhagic fever with renal syndrome caused by Hantavirus.
  • Hantaviruses belong to the genus Hantavirus within the Bunyaviridae family and are globally distributed, causing two severe and often fatal illnesses in humans: hemorrhagic fever with renal syndrome (HFRS) and hantavirus pulmonary syndrome (HPS).
  • Multiple distinct hantaviruses exist, each linked to a specific rodent host. Infected rodents remain lifelong carriers without illness, transmitting the virus horizontally among themselves.
  • Human infection occurs via inhalation of aerosols from rodent urine, feces, or saliva, with disease presence influenced by the geographic distribution of rodent reservoirs.
  • HFRS is an acute infection causing interstitial nephritis, which can progress to acute renal insufficiency or renal failure in severe cases along with hemorrhagic tendencies.
  • Laboratory rats have been linked to Hantaan outbreaks in scientific institutes and occupational exposure to rats can also cause infection. HFRS management is supportive, with prevention focusing on rodent control and avoiding contact with rodent excreta.
  • HPS primarily manifests as adult respiratory distress syndrome and has mortality rates of 30% or higher, beginning with fever, headache, and myalgia, followed by rapidly developing pulmonary edema and respiratory failure, without hemorrhagic signs.
  • Hantaviral antigens are found in endothelial cells and macrophages of the lungs, heart, spleen, and lymph nodes. The disease mechanism involves vascular endothelium damage.
  • Diagnosis uses RT-PCR for viral nucleic acid, immunohistochemistry for viral antigens, or ELISA for specific IgM antibodies. A fourfold IgG titer rise between acute and convalescent sera is also diagnostic. Containment is challenging due to biosafety requirements.
  • Treatment for HPS focuses on maintaining oxygenation and supporting hemodynamic function.

Explanation of other options:

West Nile virus (Option A): West Nile virus infection is an arboviral encephalitis which commonly presents as a febrile illness with myalgia, sometimes accompanied by a maculopapular rash on the trunk, lymphadenopathy, retroorbital pain, sore throat, nausea, vomiting, and arthralgia.

Leptospira (Option C): Leptospirosis can range from mild, flu-like illness with fever, chills, headache, muscle pain, abdominal discomfort, conjunctival suffusion, and sometimes aseptic meningitis, to severe disease known as Weil's syndrome marked by hemorrhage, jaundice, and acute kidney injury. Spread happens via breaks in the skin or through mucous membranes, particularly those of the eyes and mouth.

Brucella melitensis (Option D): Brucellosis is a bacterial disease of animals that spreads to humans either directly or indirectly, most often from infected domesticated ruminants and pigs. It typically presents with fever, often accompanied by profuse night sweats, fatigue, myalgia, headache, and chills, and may follow an undulating pattern with musculoskeletal symptoms in about half of patients.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman delivers a baby with microcephaly, spasticity, sensorineural hearing loss and retinal mottling at 38 weeks by vaginal delivery. During her first trimester, she went on a trip to Puerto Rico and had multiple mosquito bites and later developed mild fever with a rash. A serum sample from the baby is collected. Which pathogen might be the most likely causative agent?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Zika virus is a flavivirus transmitted by Aedes mosquitoes.
  • Initially considered a mild illness with rash and fever in tropical Africa and southern Asia.
  • Zika virus infection is associated with fetal microcephaly and the risk of microcephaly is highest with first-trimester infection, and other fetal outcomes include stillbirth, neural tube defects, eye abnormalities, and deafness.
  • Adult complications, though rare, include Guillain-Barré syndrome, encephalitis, leukopenia, and thrombocytopenic purpura.
  • Transmission also occurs sexually and via blood transfusion.

Explanation of other options:

Nipah virus (Option A): Nipah virus infection typically begins with an influenza-like illness that may progress to encephalitis, often accompanied by respiratory symptoms, and results in death in about half of reported cases.

Hantavirus (Option B): Hantavirus infections present mainly as hemorrhagic fever with

renal syndrome (HFRS) or hantavirus pulmonary syndrome (HPS). HFRS is characterized by acute febrile illness with interstitial nephritis that may progress to renal failure and hemorrhagic manifestations, while HPS begins with fever, headache, and myalgia, rapidly progressing to pulmonary edema and respiratory failure, typically without bleeding.

Ebola virus (Option C): Ebola virus infection typically starts after an incubation period of 2-21 days with fever, headache, sore throat, and muscle pain, followed by abdominal complaints, rash, and both internal and external bleeding. The illness often progresses to shock and can be fatal.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with hematuria, dysuria and suprapubic pain. He reports that he had a renal transplant 8 months ago and is currently on many immunosuppressants. Urinalysis is positive for blood but is negative for nitrates or leukocyte esterase. A nucleic acid amplification test of his urine is positive for a polyomavirus. Identify the virus causing this condition.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The given clinical features of hematuria and dysuria in a post-renal transplant patient is suggestive of BK virus
  • Polyomaviruses are small, nonenveloped viruses with a circular double-stranded DNA genome, enclosed in an icosahedral capsid and condensed by cellular histones.
  • BK virus, one of the human polyomaviruses, is widespread and typically acquired during early childhood, persisting in the kidneys and lymphoid tissues in a latent state.
  • It may reactivate when the immune system is suppressed, such as in renal transplant recipients, during pregnancy, or with increasing age.
  • Reactivation can lead to polyomavirus-associated nephropathy in kidney transplant patients, which is a serious complication causing graft failure in up to half of affected individuals, and can also cause hemorrhagic cystitis in bone marrow transplant recipients.

Explanation of other options:

HPV (Option A): HPV is the most prevalent viral infection of the reproductive tracts and is the primary cause of anogenital cancers. Low-risk types 6 and 11 cause most anogenital warts and laryngeal papillomas, the latter potentially obstructing the airway in children. Immunosuppressed individuals, particularly those with HIV/AIDS, have higher rates of warts and HPV-associated cancers.


JC virus (Option C): Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML) from JC virus is a late manifestation of AIDS and presents with multifocal neurological deficits such as ataxia, hemiparesis, visual field loss, aphasia, sensory changes, and sometimes seizures.


Cytomegalovirus (Option D): In immunocompromised individuals, primary CMV infections are more severe, with those undergoing hematopoietic stem cell or solid organ transplants, receiving chemotherapy for malignancies, or living with AIDS at highest risk. The infection often becomes disseminated with prolonged viral shedding, and pneumonia and colitis are the most frequent complications. Reactivation, more common in these patients, may be as virulent as primary infection despite generally being less severe in normal hosts.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents because of nasal discharge, cough, and low-grade fever for 3 days. He attends daycare, and several other children have had the same symptoms. The result of a RT-PCR for severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) is positive. Which of the following sets of findings best describes properties of this virus?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Coronaviruses are enveloped with helical symmetry and ssRNA.
  • Coronaviruses are large, enveloped RNA viruses with an unsegmented, positive-sense single-stranded RNA genome, the largest among RNA viruses. (Options B, C, and D ruled out)
  • Their helical nucleocapsid is surrounded by a lipid envelope with widely spaced, club- or petal-shaped projections that give a solar corona-like appearance.
  • Structural proteins include the nucleocapsid (N) protein, membrane (M) glycoprotein, and spike (S) glycoprotein, with some strains also producing hemagglutinin esterase (HE).
  • The genome encodes both structural and nonstructural proteins, with a high frequency of recombination during replication.
  • Viral replication occurs in the cytoplasm, where virions bud into the endoplasmic reticulum and Golgi apparatus before release.
  • Entry is mediated by binding of spike proteins to specific host receptors, such as aminopeptidase N for some human coronaviruses and angiotensin-converting enzyme 2 (ACE2) or CD26 for others.
  • In humans, classical coronaviruses cause mild upper respiratory tract illnesses ("common colds") with symptoms like nasal discharge and malaise, typically afebrile in adults, with an incubation of 2-5 days and symptom duration of about 1 week.
  • Asthmatic children may experience wheezing, and adults with chronic lung disease may have exacerbations. The lower respiratory tract is usually spared, though pneumonia can occur.
  • Novel coronaviruses can cause severe disease, including Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS) and Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS).
  • SARS-CoV has an incubation period of around 6 days and begins with fever, malaise, chills, headache, dizziness, cough, sore throat, and myalgia, progressing in some cases to shortness of breath, abnormal chest radiographs, and acute respiratory distress.
  • Death from progressive respiratory failure occurs with highest mortality in the elderly.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presents with a rash and fever that began approximately 2 days ago. According to his mother, it began as a pink rash on his face and has subsequently spread to his trunk. A rash as shown in the image and posterior auricular lymphadenopathy is noted on examination. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The given clinical features of fever, rash, and cervical lymphadenopathy suggests a diagnosis of rubella.
  • Rubella virus, the sole member of the genus Rubivirus in the Matonaviridae family, is an enveloped virus with a single-stranded positive-sense RNA
  • Rubella (German measles) is an acute febrile illness affecting mainly children and young adults, presenting with rash and lymphadenopathy, and is the mildest of the common viral exanthems.
  • Infection during early pregnancy can cause severe fetal abnormalities, including congenital malformations and mental retardation, collectively termed congenital rubella syndrome (CRS).
  • CRS can present with transient neonatal effects like rash and hepatosplenomegaly, and permanent defects such as cataracts, cardiac anomalies such as patent ductus arteriosus, sensorineural hearing loss, or developmental abnormalities emerging in childhood.
  • Central nervous system involvement leads to mental retardation and motor deficits, with possible late-onset progressive rubella panencephalitis in adolescence.
  • The virus can persist in various tissues after birth, with prolonged shedding for over a year.
  • Prevention relies on ensuring women of childbearing age are immune before pregnancy.
  • Infection in the general population occurs via the upper respiratory tract, with an incubation period of about 12 days.
  • The virus replicates in the respiratory tract, spreads to cervical lymph nodes, and viremia develops within 7-9 days, persisting until antibodies appear around day 13-15.
  • Clinically, rubella begins with malaise, low-grade fever, and a morbilliform rash starting on the face and spreading to the trunk and limbs, usually lasting under 3 days.
  • Diagnosis is difficult without laboratory confirmation due to similarity with other viral rashes. Immunity involves initial IgM followed by lifelong IgG persistence. Maternal IgG protects infants for 4-6 months.
  • Laboratory diagnosis uses nucleic acid detection, virus isolation from nasopharyngeal or throat swabs, and serology.
  • Rubella is generally a mild condition that resolves on its own, and it does not require any specific treatment.

Explanation of other options:

Rubeola (Option A): Measles also known as rubeola in nonimmune individuals typically presents after an 8-15 day incubation period with a prodrome of fever, cough, coryza, conjunctivitis with photophobia, and Koplik spots followed by a characteristic rash starting on the face and spreading to the trunk and limbs, resolving with desquamation in 5-10 days.

Roseola (Option C): Roseola infantum, caused primarily by HHV-6B, is a mild childhood illness marked by high fever followed by a skin rash. It commonly occurs in early childhood and is associated with febrile seizures in affected children.

Parvovirus infection (Option D): Parvovirus B19 infection commonly presents as erythema infectiosum, especially in young children, with a slapped cheek rash that may be accompanied by fever and mild systemic symptoms.

questions.text: A 9-year-old child was brought to the OPD with complaints of fever, abdominal pain, rash, and conjunctival injection for the past 2 days. His mother gives a history of COVID-19 infection 4 weeks back. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The given clinical features of fever with rash, abdominal complaints with a history of COVID-19 in a child is suggestive of Multisystem Inflammatory Syndrome in Children (MIS-C).
  • Multisystem Inflammatory Syndrome in Children (MIS-C) is a postinfectious hyperinflammatory condition occurring about 4-8 weeks after SARS-CoV-2 exposure, often resembling macrophage activation syndrome.
  • It presents in children, typically aged 8-12 years, with persistent fever, severe abdominal pain, rash, and possible abnormal cardiac function or hypotension.
  • Common features include myocarditis or left ventricular dysfunction, coronary artery dilation or aneurysms in 25-50% of cases, and renal involvement.
  • Other features include lymphopenia, thrombocytopenia, elevated ferritin, and a systemic proinflammatory state marked by high levels of IL-18, IL-10, IL-6, and IFN-γ-induced CXCL9.

Explanation of other options:

Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome (Option A): Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome primarily affects infants and young children under five, beginning with fever, malaise, irritability, and skin tenderness, followed by diffuse scarlatiniform erythema accentuated in flexural and periorificial areas. The skin may become wrinkled, develop flaccid blisters and erosions, and peel away with gentle pressure (Nikolsky sign), leading to moist, denuded areas that can predispose to infection, sepsis, and fluid imbalance. Healing usually occurs within 10-14 days without scarring, with conjunctivitis, pharyngitis, and superficial lip erosions common, while intraoral mucosa remains unaffected.

Kawasaki disease (Option B): Kawasaki disease typically affects children under 5 years old and is characterized by fever lasting more than 5 days. Other features include bilateral conjunctive injection, red cracked lips, and unilateral cervical lymphadenopathy.

Scarlet fever (Option D): Scarlet fever presents with a diffuse, finely papular, bright-red rash appearing within 24-48 hours of symptom onset, often starting on the neck and spreading to the trunk and extremities, with accentuation in skin creases and a rough, goose-pimple texture. Cheeks are erythematous with perioral pallor, and after 3-4 days the rash fades, followed by desquamation beginning on the face and moving downward. The tongue becomes coated with swollen papillae, later giving a strawberry-like appearance. Diagnosis is supported by typical rash features, history of recent group A streptococcal infection, and confirmation of GAS in the pharynx.

questions.text: A 2-week-old boy is brought to the Pediatric Department. His mother says that is not awakened by loud noises. She shows his eyes which appear 'cloudy' as shown in the image. On a physical exam, a continuous murmur with machine-like consistency over the precordium at the left second intercoastal space is heard. Which strain is used in making vaccines against the underlying infection?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The given clinical features of hearing loss, cataracts, and patent ductus arteriosus is suggestive of congenital rubella syndrome and the strain RA 27/3 is used in the preparation of rubella vaccine.
  • The rubella virus, the only member of the genus Rubivirus within the Matonaviridae family, is an enveloped virus containing a single-stranded, positive-sense RNA genome.
  • Rubella (German measles) is an acute febrile illness, primarily affecting children and young adults, characterized by rash and lymphadenopathy, and is considered the mildest among common viral exanthems.
  • When contracted in early pregnancy, it can cause serious fetal defects, including congenital malformations and intellectual disability, collectively known as congenital rubella syndrome (CRS).
  • CRS may manifest at birth with transient findings like rash and hepatosplenomegaly, or with permanent abnormalities such as cataracts, congenital heart defects notably patent ductus arteriosus, sensorineural deafness, and developmental delays that may emerge later in childhood.
  • Involvement of the central nervous system can lead to intellectual disability and motor impairment, with some cases developing late-onset progressive rubella panencephalitis during adolescence.
  • The virus can persist in multiple tissues after birth, with prolonged shedding for more than a year.
  • Prevention centers on ensuring immunity in women of reproductive age prior to pregnancy.
  • In the general population, transmission occurs via the upper respiratory tract, with an incubation period of around 12 days.
  • After initial replication in the respiratory tract, the virus spreads to cervical lymph nodes, and viremia appears by days 7-9, continuing until antibody formation around days 13-15.
  • Clinically, rubella starts with malaise, low-grade fever, and a morbilliform rash that begins on the face before spreading to the trunk and extremities, typically lasting less than three days.
  • Because its presentation resembles other viral exanthems, laboratory confirmation is often necessary.
  • The immune response begins with IgM production, followed by lifelong IgG persistence. Maternal IgG provides infants with temporary protection for 4-6 months.'
  • Diagnosis is made using nucleic acid testing, viral isolation from nasopharyngeal or throat swabs, and serology.
  • Rubella is usually a mild, self-limiting illness that does not require specific treatment.

Explanation of other options:

17D (Option A): The 17D strain of the yellow fever virus is used for vaccine preparation.

Edmonston Zagreb (Option C): Measles vaccines, developed from the Edmonston strain of the measles virus, provide protection against all naturally occurring wild measles viruses.

Jeryl Lynn (Option D): Jeryl Lynn strain is used in vaccination against mumps.

choices.text: Examination of stool for ova & parasites

questions.text: An 8-month-old girl has fever, vomiting, and diarrhea for 3 days. Her temperature is 101.3°F, pulse is 145/min, and blood pressure is 92/54 mm-Hg. Examination shows dry mucous membranes and decreased skin turgor. Which of the following is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The most common cause of diarrheal illness in a child is rotavirus for which enzyme immunoassay of stool is used to confirm the diagnosis.
  • Rotaviruses are a leading cause of diarrheal illness in infants and young children with occasional infections in adults.
  • They are structurally and replication-wise similar to reoviruses and are classified into eight species (A-H) based on antigenic epitopes and VP6 protein sequence, with Group A being the most frequent cause of human disease.
  • Human reoviruses include rotaviruses, which are characterized by their unique wheel-like structure as shown below and the genome consists of linear, double-stranded RNA divided into 10-12 segments.
  • The outer capsid proteins VP4 and VP7 are critical neutralizing antigens, with VP7 being the predominant antigen. Five main serotypes (G1-G4, G9) cause most human infections.
  • Pathogenesis involves infection of villus cells in the small intestine, sparing gastric and colonic mucosa. The virus multiplies in enterocyte cytoplasm, damaging transport mechanisms.
  • NSP4, a viral enterotoxin, induces secretion via calcium-dependent pathways, leading to loss of absorptive capacity, sodium and glucose malabsorption, and replacement of mature cells with immature crypt cells.
  • This disruption causes watery diarrhea, with viral shedding in stool. Symptoms in otherwise healthy individuals last 2-12 days but may persist in malnourished or immunocompromised patients. Recovery of intestinal function can take 3-8 weeks.
  • Clinically, rotavirus disease in infants and children presents after a 1-3 day incubation with watery diarrhea, fever, abdominal pain, and vomiting, often leading to dehydration. Severe cases can be fatal if untreated.
  • Infections peak in winter, are most common between ages 6 months and 2 years, and are transmitted mainly via the fecal-oral route. Nosocomial infections are frequent.
  • Immune factors like IgA and interferon may protect against severe disease. Maternal antibodies protect infants under 6 months from severe illness but do not prevent reinfection.
  • Laboratory diagnosis relies on detecting the virus in stool samples collected early in the course of illness, along with evidence of an increased antibody titer.
  • The presence of the virus in stool can be identified using antigen enzyme immunoassays (EIAs) or polymerase chain reaction (PCR). (Options A, B, and C ruled out)
  • Treatment is supportive, focusing on fluid and electrolyte replacement to prevent dehydration, acidosis, shock, and death. Control relies on sanitation, wastewater management, and vaccination.
  • The rotavirus vaccine is included in the national programme and is a live-attenuated vaccine given orally at 6, 10, and 14 weeks.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male presents with a 3-day history of fever, headache, fatigue, and muscle aches. He reports recent hiking in the Rocky Mountains and recalls being bitten by several ticks during his trip. On examination, he has a biphasic fever pattern, with no rash and mild joint pain. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The given clinical vignette of fever without rash, headache, myalgia along with history of tick bite makes Colorado tick fever the most likely diagnosis.
  • Colorado tick fever virus belongs to the genus Coltivirus in the family Reoviridae, but unlike rotaviruses and orthoreoviruses, it is vector-borne.
  • Also called mountain fever or tick fever, it is transmitted by ticks, has a single recognized antigenic type, and causes a mild febrile illness without rash.
  • The incubation period is 4-6 days, followed by sudden onset of fever, myalgia, headache, muscle and joint pain, lethargy, nausea, and vomiting.
  • Fever is typically biphasic, with an initial 2-day episode, temporary improvement, and recurrence for another 3-4 days. The disease is self-limiting.
  • The virus can be isolated from whole blood via cell cultures, with viremia lasting up to 4 weeks or longer.
  • RT-PCR detects viral RNA in red blood cells and plasma, while neutralizing antibodies appear in the second week and can be identified by plaque reduction tests.
  • ELISA and fluorescent antibody tests are also used. A single infection usually confers lasting immunity.
  • Most cases occur in young men with high tick exposure. The tick is a true reservoir, transmitting the virus transovarially, and natural infection also occurs in rodents, which serve as hosts for immature tick stages.
  • No specific treatment exists, and prevention relies on avoiding tick-infested areas and using protective clothing or repellents.

Explanation of other options:

Lyme disease (Option A): Lyme disease is caused by Borrelia species, most commonly B. burgdorferi. It typically begins with erythema migrans, a slowly expanding red skin lesion at the tick bite site, and can progress to disseminated infection with multiple skin lesions, neurologic symptoms such as meningitis, facial palsy, and neuropathies, cardiac involvement, and migratory musculoskeletal pain.

Rocky Mountain spotted fever (Option B): Rocky Mountain spotted fever (RMSF), caused by Rickettsia rickettsii and transmitted via tick bite, typically presents abruptly with high fever, extreme fatigue, muscle aches, headache, nausea, and vomiting. Within 96 hours of symptom onset, most patients develop a distinctive rash that begins as a widespread erythematous maculopapular eruption, resembling meningococcemia, and then progresses to petechiae, purpura, and, if untreated, skin necrosis or gangrene.

West Nile virus infection (Option D): West Nile fever is caused by the West Nile virus, primarily transmitted by Culex mosquitoes. It commonly presents as a febrile illness with myalgia, maculopapular rash , lymphadenopathy, and symptoms such as headache, fatigue, sore throat, nausea, vomiting, and arthralgia, but can progress in some cases to neuroinvasive disease, including meningitis, encephalitis, or acute flaccid paralysis, particularly in elderly or immunocompromised individuals.
